history.content: All individual. They're "difficult" because they pretty much completely determine your grade. Put in effort into the projects, score well on them, do whatever extra credit you can, and you'll be set for an A even if you do around average on exams. I personally loved the structure of the class and wish more classes adopted a project based grade approach but I'm also not the best exam-taker so I'm a bit biased.

children.subject: Should be, yes. Like it states on the course info page for the course "there will be other courses that will help build your teamwork skills", like 162, 164 etc.
BTW, I spent 30 hours on the first project. And around 60-70 hours on each one of the later projects. I know there are some people even spent 100 hours to perfect their project. Be bold and prepared.

I took Hilfiger with only CS61A as my programming foundations. My feeling is that his class is more suitable for the students who already had experiences of handling side projects outside the class. You need a certain level of skills and intuition about how to debug your code and kinda enjoy the process of doing it. If that's that's the case, you will pretty much learn a ton of knowledge about data structure and in the same time gain experiences of handling large projects that will eventually benefit you when u enter the industry. However, if you consider yourself not that mature on programming and lack patience and skills of debugging the code, it's better off to either take with Hug or lower your workload next semester. I took 3 technicals that semester and suffered a lot mentally and physically. Even though I went through it and managed a good grade, I still feel extremely shaky and unconfident about my understanding of data structures, since I spent way too long time fixing those silly, funky bugs of my code. Some of my friends scored below 50% in every exam but still ended up with an A because they put a ton of work the projects.

history.content: I've heard Hilfinger's projects are notorious for being difficult and time-consuming, are they all individual or are some of them partner-based? This fall, there's four projects: signpost, enigma, tablut, and gitlet.
history.subject: CS 61B Hilfinger
